review:
A classic back then, but not a purchase I'd recommend now...

Playing this in 2025, and this is strictly my opinion as someone with no nostalgia for it. I know the original game was groundbreaking in the late 90s, and I respect the history. But I am not reviewing it as a piece of history. I am reviewing what it feels like to sit down and play it today.

The game opens with a five-minute tram ride where you just sit and wait. That might have been jaw-dropping in 1998, but in 2025 it is just dead air before you get to do anything. Once I finally stepped off, the controls hit me hard. Tapping forward felt like I was sprinting at light speed. It was floaty, unnatural, and immediately immersion-breaking.

From there, the problems stacked up. Hit detection with the crowbar was sloppy. Climbing onto boxes or through windows felt like a fight with the physics. Onboarding was vague and outdated. It just came off like the game was wasting my time.

The pacing dragged. Long stretches of downtime made me feel like I was waiting for the game to get going, and when combat finally arrived, the iconic crowbar and shotgun did not make up for how clunky the encounters felt.

That said, there are some things I liked. The wall-mounted health stations are clever. Some of the enemy designs are still super cool. And I understand why this game blew people away in its time. But in 2025, none of that changed the fact that the overall experience felt rough, confusing, and unfun.

Final Verdict: 4/10
At $12.99 [CAD], I cannot recommend it. At $1 on sale, MAYBE if you are chasing nostalgia. But for new players, there are far better classics that still hold up.

While the original Half-Life remains the definitive version, Half-Life: Source offers something unexpectedly delightful: unintentional comedy gold. Yes, it's buggy. Yes, the physics and AI are wonky. But that's exactly what makes it charming.

The Good:
- Hilarious glitches that create memorable moments (scientists doing somersaults, guards screaming endlessly, physics-defying ragdolls)
- Familiar gameplay with a fresh, absurd twist
- Perfect for fans who want a lighthearted replay
- Dirt cheap during sales ($1.99)

The Bad:
- More bugs than the original
- Slightly off movement and weapon feel
- Inconsistent lighting and AI

Bottom Line: If you're a Half-Life purist seeking the authentic experience, stick with the original. But if you want to laugh at Gordon Freeman's expense while reliving a classic, Half-Life: Source transforms technical shortcomings into entertainment. It's not the best way to play Half-Life‚Äîit's the most fun way to break it.

Recommended for: Longtime fans ready for a comedic twist on a beloved classic.

There is not much that can be said about Half-Life Source. It is quintessentially, well Half-Life. 

The review that I posted about the original still stands with Source, but how is it different?

Well the overall graphics and physics have been converted from GoldSource to the Source engine featured in Half-Life 2, and that divides the fanbase, but in my opinion this is a completely fine way to experience the original classic with a fresh look and some QOL features not present in HL1. Some of the guns work differently, but the added physics elements are fine.

I would recommend the original over this version, but for 1 playthrough its worth checking this out. The story, graphics and overall gameplay remains the same so there is nothing you can lose with this edition.

15 Jahre Counter-Strike: Source ‚Äì mein R√ºckblick

Wenn ich zur√ºckdenke ist es verr√ºckt dass ich wirklich zehn Jahre lang Counter-Strike: Source gespielt habe. Angefangen hat alles weil ein Kumpel meinte ich soll es mal probieren. Aus ein paar Runden wurden N√§chte und aus N√§chten wurden Jahre.

F√ºr mich war CSS nie nur ein Shooter. Klar es ging ums Aimen und Gewinnen. Aber das Beste waren die Leute. Abende im Teamspeak, Gel√§chter, Spr√ºche und diese Insider die man nur mit der eigenen Runde versteht.

Mein erstes richtiges Clutch vergesse ich nie. Herzklopfen, zittrige H√§nde und alle haben im Headset rumgeschrien. Diese Momente bekommt man nicht oft zur√ºck.

Nat√ºrlich gab es auch die nervigen Seiten. Cheater, Lags und Abende wo einfach nichts lief. Trotzdem war CSS immer ein Teil meines Alltags und hat mich durch meine Zwanziger getragen. Oft mehr Treffpunkt als Spiel.

Heute starte ich es nur noch selten. Doch wenn ich es tue f√ºhlt es sich sofort vertraut an. So als w√§re man in einem alten Caf√© in dem alles noch so steht wie fr√ºher.

CSS war f√ºr mich ein St√ºck Jugend und ein St√ºck Freundschaft. Es war eine Zeit die ich nicht vergessen werde.
